abstracts.cdata!:
The project outcome is highly
            satisfactory, and sustainability is likely, with modest
            institutional development impacts. Both performances by the
            Bank, and Borrower, are rated highly satisfactory, based on
            the component ratings for lending, supervision, and
            outcomes, and, on project preparation, implementation and
            outcomes, respectively. But regardless of success, lessons
            suggest that: 1) the endemic nature of natural hazards in
            Bangladesh, call for a disaster preparedness to be included
            as a central part of the country assistance strategy, to
            explore if the operation of investment projects,
            particularly infrastructure financing, could include
            built-in clauses for a pre-negotiated flexibility on rapid
            disbursement, should catastrophic events occur; 2) flexible,
            but stringent fiduciary, and procurement framework should be
            established in fast-track, emergency operations, to prevent
            implementation delays based on governance issues. The
            implementation of financial management systems in this
            project, through reporting requirements, proved useful in
            taking corrective measures, and allowed flexibility for
            emergency procurement procedures; 3) the timely emergency
            assistance generated considerable goodwill to ease
            resolution of differences on difficult development issues;
            and, 4) program finance for disaster recovery should be
            explored, to be treated as a recurrent expenditure, in cases
            such as Bangladesh.

5084331.majtheme: Economic management,Social protection and risk management

abstracts.cdata!:
The Emergency Flood Recovery Project
            will assist the Government in maintaining macroeconomic
            stability while helping to finance import costs associated
            with restoring infrastructure assets, production levels, and
            food grain stocks. This is the first part of International
            Development Association's three-part strategy to help
            Bangladesh respond to the 1998 floods. The project will
            provide assistance for: 1) the agricultural sector, to
            ensure that farmers have adequate supplies of seeds,
            fertilizers, and other agricultural inputs for planing the
            next boro rice crops; 2) additional food grain imports in
            order to maintain and augment food grain stocks that will
            otherwise be depleted with the partial loss of two rice
            crops; 3) the manufacturing sector, in order to enable
            manufacturers to import machinery, spare parts, and other
            raw materials; and 4) additional imports of fuel, cement,
            and other construction materials that are needed for relief
            operations and rehabilitation of physical infrastructure.
